The Australia Institute - Wikipedia The Australia Institute From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Jump to navigation Jump to search Organization ‹ The template Infobox organization is being considered for merging. › The Australia InstituteAbbreviationThe Australia InstituteFormation4 May 1994[1]TypePublic policy think tankDirectorBen OquistWebsitetai.org.au The Australia Institute is a progressive Australian think tank conducting public policy research on a broad range of economic, social, transparency and environmental issues in order to inform public debate and bring greater accountability to the democratic process. The institute consists of members who support the Labor party and Unions, who advocate the welfare of the working class. The Australia Institute is based in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory. Contents 1 Philosophy 2 Research 2.1 Climate change and energy 2.2 Tax reform debate 2.3 Centre for Future Work 2.4 The Australia Institute Tasmania 3 Funding 4 Directors 5 References 6 External links Philosophy[edit] The Australia Institute describes itself as "one of the country’s most influential think tanks", as well as saying that:The Institute is determined to push public debate beyond the simplistic question of whether markets or governments have all the answers to more important questions: When does government need to intervene in the market? When should it stand back? And when regulation is needed, what form should it take?[2] The Australia Institute has been variously described as left-leaning,[3] independent,[4] progressive[5][6] or centrist.[7] Research[edit] The Australia Institute's researchers are prominent commentators on public policy issues, including work on climate change and energy, emissions trading, taxation policy and inequality. The Australia Institute is also known for its work on environment, taxation, health, consumer affairs and trade practices.[citation needed] Climate change and energy[edit] The Australia Institute is active in promoting global warming mitigation measures, and has been critical of the Australian federal government's perceived lack of action on climate change. The Australia Institute was critical of the Howard Government's decision to refuse to ratify the Kyoto Protocol. It claims that the former Prime Minister and some senior ministers deny the scientific evidence for global warming and that the resources sector drives government energy policy. Leaked minutes of a meeting between the Energy Minister, the Prime Minister and fossil fuel lobbyists provide evidence for these claims.[8][9] The Australia Institute has been active in promoting renewable energy development, and other mitigation measures, and it has campaigned strongly against developing a nuclear industry in Australia.[10] The Australia Institute criticised the Rudd Government's proposed Australian emissions trading scheme (or Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme), arguing that it failed to adequately take into account voluntary action and delivered excessive compensation to polluting industries.[11] The Australia Institute spoke positively of the design of the carbon price mechanism implemented by the Gillard Government, arguing that beginning with a fixed price and transitioning to an emissions trading scheme made sense given that there was no consensus about what the emissions reduction target should be.[12] In 2014, Ben Oquist (then the Australia Institute's Strategy Director) was involved in the Palmer United Party's decision to vote against the abolition of the Renewable Energy Target, the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and the Climate Change Authority.[13] Oquist wrote that "The Australia Institute is disappointed that the carbon price is likely to be repealed" but that "The Palmer-Gore announcement has re-set climate policy and politics. Keeping the CCA, the RET and the CEFC is much more than most expected from the PUP. We have avoided a big step backwards."[14] In 2017, the Australia Institute reported that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions were "rising rapidly" since the abolition of the carbon price, with economist Matt Grudnoff criticising the National Energy Guarantee proposed by the Turnbull Government, saying that it would be “likely to cause our emissions to rise even faster”.[15] In 2017, The Australia Institute took over The Climate Institute's intellectual property after that institute closed, and subsequently launched a Climate and Energy Program to continue the work.[16][17] The first Climate of the Nation report produced by The Australia Institute was released in 2018. Tax reform debate[edit] The Australia Institute employs several economists[18] who have published papers arguing for tax reform, particularly in the areas of superannuation tax concessions, negative gearing, capital gains tax and goods and services tax.[19] During the 2016 Australian federal election, the Institute published a series of critiques of the Coalition's proposed policy of cutting the company tax rate.[20] The Australia Institute has also criticised the final two stages of the Turnbull Government's three-stage income tax cut plan, releasing research into how the benefits from the tax cut are distributed by income [21] and electorate.[22] Centre for Future Work[edit] In 2016, the Australia Institute set up the Centre for Future of Work "to conduct and publish progressive economic research on work, employment, and labour markets".[23] Its founding director is Canadian economist Dr Jim Stanford. The Australia Institute Tasmania[edit] In 2017, the Australia Institute established The Australia Institute Tasmania with director Leanne Minshull, to "look at political, social and economic issues on a state level, and release research and polling on government policies and issues of the day".[24] Funding[edit] The Australia Institute had a total gross income of $4.46 Million[25] in 2020 and is independently funded by donations from philanthropic trusts and individuals, as well as grants and commissioned research from business, unions and non-government organisations. In its first decade through to 2003, the Australia Institute was largely funded by the Poola Foundation and the Treepot Foundation—philanthropic organisations run by the Kantors.[3] Other significant funders include the McKinnon Family Foundation; David Morawetz’s Social Justice Fund, a sub fund of the Australian Communities Foundation; Diana and Brian Snape AM and the Susan McKinnon Foundation.[26] In recent years, the Australia Institute has reported the number of donations it has received from individuals, with 2,000 individual donors in financial year 2015 [27] and 2,700 in financial year 2017.[28] The Australia Institute does not accept donations or commissioned work from political parties.[2] Directors[edit] Dr John McKinnon (Chair), NGO director and philanthropist Ms Alex Sloan, award winning journalist, interviewer and facilitator Mr Andrew Dettmer, National President of the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union Professor Asmi Wood, Australian National University College of law. Dr Elizabeth Cham, former CEO of Philanthropy Australia (96-06) Dr Elizabeth Hill, Senior Lecturer, Political economy at the University of Sydney Mr Josh Bornstein, Head of National Employment and Industrial Law at Maurice Blackburn Lawyers Former board members include: Lin Hatfield Dodds, National Director, UnitingCare Australia Sarah Maddison (Chair), Senior Associate Dean, School of Politics and International Relations, University of New South Wales Tony McMichael, Professor, National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, Australian National University Meredith Edwards, Emeritus Professor, University of Canberra Sharan Burrow, President, Australian Council of Trade Unions Mark Wootton, Principal and Manager of Jigsaw Farms and Director of the Poola Charitable Foundation Hugh Saddler, Managing Director, Energy Strategies Limited Gerardine (Ged) Kearney, President, Australian Council of Trade Unions Ben Oquist, Executive Director, The Australia Institute Richard Denniss, Chief Economist, The Australia Institute Lee Thomas, Federal Secretary, Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation Max Neutze, Professor, Urban Research Program, Australian National University, inaugural chair Dr David Morawetz, Clinical/Counseling Psychologist, Founder/Director of the Social Justice Fund Professor Barbara Pocock (Deputy Chair), Director, Centre for Work and Life, University of South Australia References[edit] ^ Kirby, Michael. The B Team | Credibility The B team Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Who we are Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Search Menu Credibility In accordance to our mission and belief in transparency, The B Team is committed to being accountable to our mission, our partner organizations, our donors and supporters. How we are funded Close to 57% of The B Team’s funding comes from the Founders Circle, a group comprised of many of our Leaders, Foundations and individuals, who provide unrestricted support to the organization. We are also funded by a growing group of programmatic funders who provide restricted support, tied to one or more of our Causes, with the aim to scale the impact of these efforts. How we use our funding Unrestricted funding is allocated across the organization, in line with the priorities set by the Board to achieve our mission. Programmatic funding is distributed based on the objectives and deliverables of each cause area in partnership with each donor. Financial Statements and Form 990s 2014 Form 9902014 Financial Statement2015 Form 9902015 Financial Statement2016 Form 9902016 Financial Statement2017 Form 9902017 Financial Statement2018 Form 9902018 Financial Statement2019 Form 9902019 Financial Statement The B Team Headquarters Inc is a registered 503(c)(3), operating from New York state. We have a wholly owned subsidiary in the UK, a limited company: The B Team Headquarters UK Limited. These organizations house our team in two offices, our Headquarters in New York City and a satellite office in London. Our registered office addresses are: Headquarters: The B Team Headquarters Inc.115 5th Avenue6th FloorNew York, NY 10003 Subsidiary:The B Team Headquarters UK Limited20 Farringdon StreetLondonEC4A 4EN The governing body of The B Team is our global board, a subset of The B Team Leaders, who are responsible for setting strategy, monitoring our finances, agreeing to the allocation of resources and monitoring our outcomes. Board Directors have a two-year term and are elected and overseen by the Board Members. We have two active Board Committees, the Audit Committee and the Nominations Committee, and two Officers of the Board.BoardSir Richard Branson, Nominations CommitteeSharon Burrow, Vice-Chair, Audit CommitteeKathy Calvin, Audit CommitteeDavid Crane, Chair, Audit CommitteeDr. Mo IbrahimYolanda KakabadseIsabelle Kocher, Audit CommitteeAndrew LiverisJean OelwangPaul Polman, Chair, Nominations CommitteeJochen Zeitz, Nominations Committee Officers Halla TómasdóttirKate Ormiston Smith *Nominations Committee also comprises honorary members, other B Team Leaders, who are not Board Directors The B Team Headquarters UK Limited has Kate Ormiston Smith and Ruth Jones as employee directors. The strategy and policies are as those from the global board, incorporating relevant UK laws where applicable. The B Team | Leaders The B team Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Who we are Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Search Menu Photo by Chris Farber Leaders We are global business and civil society leaders working to confront the current crisis of conformity in leadership. We believe that for a better tomorrow for our communities, our companies and our planet, we need bold leadership now.This shared value has brought together a close community of peers where difficult decisions can be embraced, and timely, large-scale change can be achieved. We are driven by a clear strategy and dedicate our collective influence to encourage others—and ourselves—to take personal risks to do what is right. We at The B Team choose to take the more difficult yet more rewarding path. Leaders Sir Richard Branson Co-Founder of The B Team Read more Sir Richard Branson Co-Founder of The B Team “I believe business must be leading, and not waiting on, the shift toward an inclusive future. I joined The B Team to stand at the forefront of this movement and inspire others to join.” Sir Richard Branson is the Co-Founder of The B Team and Founder of the Virgin Group. Richard serves on the Climate Working Group and The B Team Australia Network Steering Committee. As a B Team Leader, his efforts are helping to build a net-zero economy that leaves people and communities thriving and resilient. Close modal Jochen Zeitz Co-Founder of The B Team Read more Jochen Zeitz Co-Founder of The B Team “Business cannot ignore the impact it has on people and our planet. I co-founded The B Team to help ensure that impact is a positive one—and one the private sector views proactively.” Jochen Zeitz is Co-Founder of The B Team and ZEITZ MOCAA, Founder of the Zeitz Foundation and The Long Run, and former Chairman and CEO of PUMA SE. Jochen serves on The B Team Africa Network Steering Committee and helps drive The B Team’s efforts to advocate for corporate sustainability governance both regionally and globally. Jochen’s work as a B Team Leader also helps companies quantify and act on environmental risk. Close modal Paul Polman Chair of The B Team Read more Paul Polman Chair of The B Team “If you don’t bring purpose to business, citizens of the world will ask: why are you around in the first place? I joined The B Team to build a private sector driven by purpose.” Paul Polman is Chair of The B Team, Co-Founder & Chair of Imagine and Former CEO of Unilever (2009-2018). Paul serves on The B Team’s Climate and Governance Working Groups. His dedication across these causes has helped to catalyze business action and advocacy on open company ownership, protection of human rights and a just transition. Close modal Sharan Burrow Vice-Chair of The B Team Read more Sharan Burrow Vice-Chair of The B Team “The world’s working people need a new social contract. That’s why I joined The B Team—to create the dialogue in partnership with business, civil society and governments for a new social contract to advance social progress for all.” Sharan Burrow is Vice-Chair of The B Team and General Secretary of the International Trade Union Confederation. Sharan serves on The B Team Australia Network Steering Committee and the Climate, Governance and Workplace Equality Working Groups. Sharan’s commitment across The B Team’s causes helps ensure a future of decent, safe and healthy work for all. Close modal Ajay Banga Executive Chairman, Mastercard Read more Ajay Banga Executive Chairman, Mastercard “From rising temperatures to rising inequality, we are facing some of the most trying challenges of our time and none of us will succeed unless we all can succeed. I joined The B Team to partner with this esteemed group of individuals as we look to tackle these large societal challenges.” Ajay Banga is executive chairman of the board of directors of Mastercard. He moved into this role following 11 years as the company’s president and chief executive officer. He is also chairman of the International Chamber of Commerce. A longtime advocate for diversity, inclusion and belonging at work, Ajay brings his experiences in building a workplace that strives to win with decency and in supporting governments as they build economies that work for all to The B Team’s efforts to chart the path toward leading with sustainability, equality and accountability. Close modal Oliver Bäte CEO, Allianz Group Read more Oliver Bäte CEO, Allianz Group “Companies have responsibilities toward society, which go beyond their own shareholders. I joined The B Team to help businesses realize these responsibilities for a shared future that benefits all.” Oliver Bäte is CEO of Allianz Group. Oliver serves on The B Team’s Climate and Governance Working Groups. His work as a B Team Leader is helping to catalyse business action toward a net-zero economy ripe with opportunity for all people. Close modal Marc Benioff Founder, Chairman and CEO, Salesforce Read more Marc Benioff Founder, Chairman and CEO, Salesforce “As business leaders we have a responsibility to all stakeholders—customers, employees, partners, communities and the environment—not shareholders alone.” Marc Benioff is Founder, Chairman and CEO of Salesforce. As a B Team Leader, Marc has helped spearhead our engagement with entrepreneurs. His commitment to economic and social equality is helping to further business action toward improving the state of the world. Close modal Jesper Brodin Chief Executive Officer, Ingka Group (IKEA) Read more Jesper Brodin Chief Executive Officer, Ingka Group (IKEA) "Together we have a decade to prevent irreversible damage from climate change to the home we all share, the planet. I joined The B Team to spark real change–we need to take a positive, proactive and collaborative approach to turn the climate challenge into scalable solutions–together. It’s good business to be a good business and the time for talk is over. We will act, now." Jesper Brodin is Chief Executive Officer of Ingka Group (IKEA). Jesper brings his experience in building business practices and products with sustainability and equality at their core to The B Team's effort to lead the path toward an inclusive economy. Close modal Kathy Calvin Former President and CEO, UN Foundation Read more Kathy Calvin Former President and CEO, UN Foundation “The just and sustainable future we envision for 2030 and beyond is only possible through collaboration. I joined The B Team to partner with innovators across sectors to help bring this vision to life.” Kathy Calvin is the Former President and CEO of the UN Foundation. Kathy serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. Her work as a B Team Leader helps develop a thriving and resilient net-zero world, which eliminates poverty and ensures equality for all. Close modal David Crane Former CEO, NRG Energy and Clean Energy Investor Read more David Crane Former CEO, NRG Energy and Clean Energy Investor “When you recognize that your company or industry is contributing to rising global temperatures that endanger our children and climate-driven societal injustices, you have a moral imperative to act. That’s why I joined The B Team—to show that the private sector can lead the way to a more sustainable and equitable future.” David Crane is the former CEO of NRG Energy. He serves as co-chair of The B Team’s Climate Working Group. A clean energy crusader, David’s work as a B Team Leader is fundamental to accelerating the shift to a net-zero economy that benefits all. Close modal Emmanuel Faber Former Chairman and CEO, Danone Read more Emmanuel Faber Former Chairman and CEO, Danone “Without fairness, there is no way we can create an economy that will tackle our collective challenges of today: inequalities, health, migrations, climate. That’s why I joined The B Team—to collectively face these challenges today, for a better tomorrow.” Emmanuel Faber is the Chairman and CEO of Danone. He serves on The B Team’s Equality Working Group. As a B Team Leader, Emmanuel is helping to foster inclusive workplace cultures that build a thriving future for both people and business. Close modal Christiana Figueres Founding Partner, Global Optimism and Convenor of Mission 2020 Read more Christiana Figueres Founding Partner, Global Optimism and Convenor of Mission 2020 “Without optimism, it is almost impossible to tackle any large challenge. And without collaboration across unusual sectors, getting things done takes way too long. I joined The B Team to accelerate these crucial cross-sector conversations and partnerships.” Christiana Figueres is Founding Partner of Global Optimism, Convenor of Mission 2020 and former Executive Secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (2010-2016). Christiana serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. She is a tireless optimist and advocate for cross-sector ambition and collaboration to address the impacts of climate change. Close modal Mats Granryd Director General, GSMA Read more Mats Granryd Director General, GSMA “Building a truly equal world is not something that any of us can do alone—as individuals, as companies, even as an industry. But working together, we truly can make a difference—that’s why I joined The B Team.” Mats Granryd is Director General of the GSMA. He serves as Co-Chair of The B Team’s Workplace Equality Working Group. An advocate for gender equality and responsible business leadership in an increasingly disruptive digital landscape, Mats’ work on The B Team helps to build a future where all communities, consumers and companies can succeed. Close modal André Hoffmann Vice Chairman, Roche Holding AG Read more André Hoffmann Vice Chairman, Roche Holding AG "Business can be a force for good, as long as its purpose is not merely to make money but to serve the community and satisfy societal needs sustainably" André Hoffmann is Vice-Chairman of Roche Holding AG and Board Trustee of the World Economic Forum and the Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution. As a leading voice in conservation and sustainability, André brings a wealth of experience in advocating for an approach to climate action that accounts for nature and biodiversity. Close modal Arianna Huffington Founder and CEO, Thrive Global Read more Arianna Huffington Founder and CEO, Thrive Global "We need to redefine success. True, sustainable success has to be built around purpose and well-being. More and more companies are realizing that what’s good for their people is also good for their business and the planet. I joined the B Team to accelerate this culture shift." Arianna Huffington is the Founder and CEO of Thrive Global. She serves on The B Team’s Workplace Equality Working Group. Arianna’s dedication to creating sustainable and purpose-driven workplaces is crucial to a private sector that prioritizes people and planet alongside profit. Close modal Dr. Mo Ibrahim Founder, Celtel and Founder and Chair, Mo Ibrahim Foundation Read more Dr. Mo Ibrahim Founder, Celtel and Founder and Chair, Mo Ibrahim Foundation “Business is essentially a force for good. I joined the B Team to work on strengthening corporate governance and transparency.” Dr. Mo Ibrahim is the Founder of Celtel and the Founder and Chair of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation and Chair of Satya Capital Limited. He serves on The B Team Africa Network Steering Committee and as Co-Chair of The B Team’s Governance Working Group. With a focus on responsible tax and beneficial ownership transparency, Mo’s stewardship as B Team Leader helps to support good governance globally and exceptional leadership across Africa. Close modal Yolanda Kakabadse Former President, World Wildlife Fund International Read more Yolanda Kakabadse Former President, World Wildlife Fund International “Business is a natural lever to help catalyze change. Building solutions to some of the biggest challenges our world faces relies on advancing this power and collaboration—that’s why I joined The B Team.” Conservationist Yolanda Kakabadse is the Former President of World Wildlife Fund International (WWF). She serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. With a breadth of experience in both government and civil society, Yolanda’s leadership on The B Team underscores the importance of cross-sector collaboration when working to secure a healthy and prosperous planet. Close modal Isabelle Kocher Former CEO, Engie Read more Isabelle Kocher Former CEO, Engie “We’re entering a new era for business. It’s no longer a choice to operate for the benefit of the environment and society. I joined The B Team to help companies realize that there is no winning company on a losing planet.” Isabelle Kocher is the former CEO of Engie. She serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. Her work as a B Team Leader is helping to accelerate the shift toward a net-zero emissions economy that builds strong communities, decent jobs and competitive markets. Close modal Guilherme Leal Co-Founder and Co-Chair, Natura Read more Guilherme Leal Co-Founder and Co-Chair, Natura “The big changes we seek will not be promoted by a single country, sector or organization. We need to work in partnership. I joined The B Team to work in tandem with leaders across sectors to transform the way we do business.” Business and social entrepreneur Guilherme Leal is the Co-Founder and Co-Chair of Natura & Co. As a B Team Leader, his work is fundamental to demonstrating and advancing successful, purpose-driven entrepreneurship that keeps people and planet at its core. Close modal Andrew Liveris Chairman Emeritus and Former Chief Executive Officer, Dow Chemical Read more Andrew Liveris Chairman Emeritus and Former Chief Executive Officer, Dow Chemical “The collective will of all of us has to be organized in a way that creates the intersection of business, government, and civil society under one title: humanity. I joined The B Team to advance this collective humanity.” Andrew Liveris is the Chairman Emeritus and Former Chief Executive Officer of Dow Chemical. He serves on The B Team Australia Network Steering Committee and the Climate and Workplace Equality Working Groups. As a B Team Leader, Andrew has ensured that the manufacturing industry is a key stakeholder in collective efforts to radically reduce carbon emissions and secure a net-zero economy. Close modal Hiro Mizuno UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments Read more Hiro Mizuno UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments "It’s the mutual responsibilities of investors and corporates to promote long-term sustainable economic growth. Investors must accelerate business transformation for a sustainable and inclusive society. B Team Leaders understand our responsibilities and more importantly know how to do it profitably." Hiro Mizuno is the UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments and the Former Executive Management Director and CIO of Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF). Prior to joining GPIF, he was a partner of Coller Capital, a London-based private equity firm. He previously worked for Sumitomo Trust & Banking Co., Ltd. in Japan, Silicon Valley and New York. He also serves as a member of Board of the Principles for Responsible Investment and as a World Economic Forum Global Future Council member. Close modal Indra Nooyi Former Chairman and CEO, PepsiCo Read more Indra Nooyi Former Chairman and CEO, PepsiCo “We are past the point of recognizing that the health of our companies, our communities, and our countries is inextricably linked. For an inclusive and thriving future, it’s time to move from talk to action, which is why I joined The B Team.” Indra Nooyi is the Former Chairman and CEO of PepsiCo. She serves on The B Team’s Workplace Equality Working Group. As a B Team Leader, Indra is focused on helping companies take action to prioritize the health and well-being of their communities, customers and planet. Close modal Jean Oelwang Founding CEO and President, Virgin Unite Read more Jean Oelwang Founding CEO and President, Virgin Unite "I’m honored to be joining a group of leaders who are committed to realizing a better way of doing business for humanity and the planet. I look forward to working collectively to tackle unacceptable issues, to heal divisions and to create an economic system that benefits all." Jean is the founding CEO and President of Virgin Unite. She has helped corporations put the wellbeing of people and the planet at their core, including working with over 25 Virgin businesses across 15 industries to help embed purpose in all they do. Over the last 15 years, Jean has worked with partners to lead the incubation and start-up of several global initiatives, including Virgin Unite and The B Team’s 100% Human at Work Network. Close modal Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala Chair, Gavi: The Vaccine Alliance, Former Finance Minister, Nigeria and Former Managing Director, World Bank Read more Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala Chair, Gavi: The Vaccine Alliance, Former Finance Minister, Nigeria and Former Managing Director, World Bank “What the world needs is a new dialogue: one that brings the private and public sectors together to stand up for what is right. I joined The B Team to evolve this dialogue for a fair future.” Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala is Chair of Gavi: The Vaccine Alliance, Former Finance Minister for Nigeria and Former Managing Director of the World Bank. She serves on The B Team Africa Network Steering Committee, Climate Working Group and as Co-Chair of The B Team’s Governance Working Group. Ngozi’s leadership at The B Team has been fundamental to holding the powerful to account, catalyzing transparent governance and helping to build trust in crucial institutions. Close modal Torben Möger Pedersen CEO, PensionDanmark Read more Torben Möger Pedersen CEO, PensionDanmark "The mission of creating a more sustainable and inclusive world is as important as ever and there is huge responsibility for those with power to help facilitate a change. The boldness of The B Team stands out in the endeavor to realize the green transition and combat growing inequalities across the globe." Torben Möger Pedersen is the CEO of PensionDanmark. As a leading asset owner, Torben brings experience in advocating for an approach to investing that includes the health of people and the planet to The B Team's efforts to accelerate the transition to a net-zero economy by 2050. Close modal François-Henri Pinault Chairman and CEO, Kering Read more François-Henri Pinault Chairman and CEO, Kering “It is my conviction that sustainable business is smart business. It gives us an opportunity to create value while helping to make a better world. I joined The B Team to seize and build upon that opportunity.” François-Henri Pinault is Chairman & CEO of Kering. He serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. As a B Team Leader, his efforts to end gender-based violence helps to secure workplaces worldwide that are just, equal and free from harassment. Close modal Mary Robinson Former President of Ireland and Chair, The Elders Read more Mary Robinson Former President of Ireland and Chair, The Elders “I am confident that if we put our mind to it business can help build the inclusive economy of tomorrow. For the benefit of our world’s most vulnerable, business cannot remain silent or inactive. I joined The B Team to help spark this private sector action.” Former President of Ireland, Mary Robinson, is Chair of The Elders. She serves as Co-Chair of The B Team’s Climate Working Group. Mary’s leadership has helped bring justice to the forefront of the climate agenda—justice for those most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change: the poor, the disempowered and the marginalized across the world. Close modal Hamdi Ulukaya Founder, Chairman and CEO, Chobani Read more Hamdi Ulukaya Founder, Chairman and CEO, Chobani “We need companies to step up and do their part. It’s not a choice, it’s a responsibility. I joined The B Team to create a sense of urgency among all business leaders to not just talk—but to act.” Hamdi Ulukaya is the Founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Chobani. He serves on The B Team’s Equality Working Group. Hamdi’s work as a B Team Leader helps to shape new corporate leadership norms around valuing inclusivity, community and responsibility. Close modal Zhang Yue Chairman and Founder, Broad Group China Read more Zhang Yue Chairman and Founder, Broad Group China “Sustainable development is critical in an era where social transformation and accelerating urbanization is occurring in many countries. As a B Team Leader I have the opportunity to advance rapid low-carbon revolution in the global architecture and transportation.” Zhang Yue is Chairman and Founder of Broad Group China. Zhang serves on The B Team’s Climate Working Group. He is dedicated to advancing energy efficient technologies, particularly around energy reservation and lightweight transportation. His efforts as a B Team Leader are helping to ensure businesses and cities scale in a sustainable and minimally impactful way. Close modal Professor Muhammad Yunus Chairman, Yunus Centre Read more Professor Muhammad Yunus Chairman, Yunus Centre “The best way to cultivate a sustainable business is to solve humanity's greatest problems. I joined The B Team to encourage business models that drive these solutions and empower people at all levels of society.” Nobel Peace Laureate Professor Muhammad Yunus is Chairman of the Yunus Centre, Founder of Grameen Bank and Yunus Social Business. His efforts to create economic and social development for those in most-need has engendered greater levels of financial inclusion and economic opportunity for women around the world. Close modal What We Lead With: 1 Purpose and Principles Leading with purpose means examining why it is you do what you do—and that isn’t to make a profit. Purpose sets forth intentions that will make a tangible difference in the world. But purpose alone is not enough. It might be a starting point, but leaders need a strong set of principles to bring their purpose to life. And at this crucial turning point for leadership, we believe there are three principles leaders must holistically and boldly embrace: sustainability, equality and accountability. 2 Humility Leaders operating with humility have an honest understanding of their strengths and limitations. They are not seeking to be the hero of their company, but rather a part of a community. A humble leader actively and continually admits to their imperfections while seeking to learn and grow. 3 Courage Courageous leaders are willing to take a personal risk for what is right and use their voice when it matters most. They choose to take the often difficult yet more rewarding path. They acknowledge that the global economic model is broken, but it did not break itself and they have a responsibility to repair it. Jochen Zeitz - Wikipedia Jochen Zeitz From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Jump to navigation Jump to search Jochen Zeitz (born 6 April 1963) is the president, CEO and chairman of the board of Harley Davidson, Inc.[1] He served as the chairman and CEO of Puma for 18 years. He also served as board member of Kering, the luxury goods company, and chaired their Sustainability Committee, for whom he developed its global sustainability strategy. Zeitz is currently a board member of Harley Davidson, The B Team, Cranemere, and the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS). In addition to this Zeitz previously served on the board of Wilderness Safaris. Jochen Zeitz is also the co-founder of The B Team[2] with Sir Richard Branson, Zeitz MOCAA and Founder of the Zeitz Foundation to support sustainable solutions that balance conservation, community, culture and commerce, and The Long Run. Contents 1 Early life 2 Career 3 Philanthropy 3.1 Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa (Zeitz MOCAA) 4 Writing 5 Honours and awards 6 References 7 External links Early life[edit] Zeitz was born in Mannheim, Germany. He studied in Germany, Italy, France, and the United States, and graduated from the European Business School in International Marketing and Finance. Career[edit] Zeitz began his professional career with Colgate-Palmolive in New York and Hamburg. He joined PUMA in 1990, and in 1993 was appointed Chairman and CEO, becoming the youngest CEO in German history to head a public company at the age of 30. He then spearheaded the worldwide restructuring of PUMA, which was in financial difficulties at the time, and implemented a long-term development plan[3][4] that saw PUMA's share price gain around 4000 percent[5] in 13 years, from 8.6 Euros in his first year as CEO to an all-time high of 350 Euros[6] when the majority stake of the company was acquired by Kering in 2007. Zeitz turned PUMA from a failing company into one of the top three sporting goods brands in the world. After acquiring PUMA Jochen Zeitz then joined Kering as a board member. In 2008 Zeitz introduced PUMAVision, an ethical framework defined by the four key principles of being fair, honest, positive and creative as applied to all professional behavior, business procedures and relationships throughout and outside of PUMA.[7] Zeitz conceived of the Environmental Profit & Loss Account (E P&L).[8] In May 2011 he announced PUMA's Environmental Profit & Loss Account,[9] which puts a monetary value to a businesses use of ecosystem services across the entire supply chain. From 2010 to 2012, Zeitz was CEO of the Sport & Lifestyle division and Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) of Kering, then a Director of Kering and Chairman of the Board's sustainable development committee. Zeitz is now the Chairman, President and CEO of Harley-Davidson since March 2020. He has been a member of the Board of Directors of Harley-Davidson since 2007 and served as the Chair of Harley-Davidson’s Sustainability Committee since its inception in 2011. In 2014, Zeitz co-founded The B Team with Sir Richard Branson, an initiative which brings together the world’s top business leaders to promote socially and environmentally conscious business practices across the globe. Zeitz is also a board member of The B Team, Cranemere, the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS). Philanthropy[edit] In 2008 Zeitz founded the not-for-profit Zeitz Foundation for Intercultural Ecosphere Safety to support creative and innovative sustainable projects and solutions that balance conservation, community development, culture, and commerce (the "4Cs") in a quadruple bottom line approach, promoting an inclusive, holistic paradigm of conservation that enhances livelihoods and fosters intercultural dialogue while building sustainable businesses. Owner of Segera (an eco-safari retreat and founding Long Run Destination), Zeitz also preserves 50,000 acres of wildlife habitat in Kenya which follows this holistic 4C philosophy to sustainably support its local communities and provide a safe refuge for endangered wildlife. Founded by Jochen Zeitz and the ZEITZ foundation in 2009, The Long Run is a membership organisation of nature-based tourism businesses that are committed to driving sustainability through a holistic 4C philosophy. Safeguarding over 21 million acres of nature in 22 different countries, touching the lives of over 750,000 people and protecting over 30,000 plant and animal species, The Long Run has become the largest organisation of its kind worldwide. Zeitz is also Vice-President of Fauna and Flora International. Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa (Zeitz MOCAA)[edit] Main article: Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa V&A Waterfront grain silo after being repurposed to house MoCAA The Zeitz Collection was founded in 2002. Since 2008 it has committed to becoming one of the most representative collections of contemporary art from the African continent and its diaspora. The Zeitz Collection bought 85 works at the 2013 Venice Biennale, including the award-winning installation at the Angola pavilion by artist Edson Chagas, a series of photographs by Zanele Muholi from the South Africa pavilion, and three large sculptures by Michele Mathison in the Zimbabwe pavilion.[10] In partnership with the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront, Zeitz founded the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa (Zeitz MOCAA), located in the historic grain silo in Cape Town's Victoria & Alfred Waterfront.[11][12][13] The museum features 9,500 square meters (102,000 square feet) of space over nine floors, including 6,000 square meters (65,000 square feet) for displays. In 2014, Thomas Heatherwick was chosen to design the conversion of the 1920s granary into a museum, including 80 galleries, 18 education rooms, a rooftop sculpture garden as well as storage and conservation areas, a restaurant, a coffee shop, and bookstores.[14] The official public opening of the museum took place in September 2017.[15] The opening ceremony was presided over by Archbishop Emeritus Desmond Tutu.[16] In the first year of opening the Zeitz MOCAA was visited by over 300000 people and named one of the best museums in the world by the Time Magazine.[17] Writing[edit] In 2010, Zeitz co-wrote and published Prayer, Profit and Principles – Monk and Manager in dialogue with Anselm Grün, a Benedictine monk.[18] The book has been translated into 15 languages and covers topics such as sustainability, the economy and prosperity, culture, values, success and responsibility. In 2014 Zeitz co-wrote and published The Breakthrough Challenge: 10 Ways to Connect Today's Profits with Tomorrow's Bottom Line with John Elkington.[19] Honours and awards[edit] Zeitz has received the "Strategist of the Year" three times from the Financial Times,[20] "Entrepreneur of the Year",[21] “Trendsetter of the Year” and “Best of European Business Award 2006″.[22] In 2004, he was awarded the Federal Cross of Merit of Germany.[23] In 2009, he was named Honorary Warden of Kenya by the Kenya Wildlife Service.[24] In 2010, the German Sustainability Foundation gave Zeitz an award for Germany's most sustainable future strategies.[25] He was named a Conde Nast Traveler “Visionaries 2012”[26] and one of Fast Company’s “10 Most Important Players at the Rio +20 Conference”.[27] He received the 2012 German Image Award,[28] the 2013 Banksia International Award[29] and the Visionary Award for the 2013 Travel + Leisure Global Vision Award.[30] In 2015 he was awarded the Special Advocacy Award for Responsible Capitalism.[31][32] The award ceremony was held at Lancaster House in London, and presented by Sajid Javid, Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills. In the same year, he was ranked #18 of "The World's Top 100 Compassionate Business Leaders" by Salt Magazine and awarded for his advocacy of Responsible Capitalism by FIRST Magazine. In 2016, the Zoological Society of London honoured Zeitz as a ZSL Conservation Fellow. In 2017, Zeitz was named #26 in OOOM's "The World's Most Inspiring People" list. In 2019, Conde Nast Traveler named Zeitz as one of “The 44 People Changing the Way We Travel”.[33] References[edit] ^ https://www.harley-davidson.com/us/en/about-us/hd-news/2020/jochen-zeitz-appointed-president-and-ceo-hd.html ^ "Call in the B Team". The B Team | Our Mission The B team Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Who we are Who we are Leaders Our Mission Our history Our Supporters Our Team Our work Our work What we do Causes: Climate Workplace Equality Governance Our movement Our movement The B Movement Our Networks Regional B Team Networks 100% Human at Work Network Our thinking Our thinking Thought leadership News Reports Search Menu Our Mission Society deserves economies that are sustainable, trusted and strong. The public is calling for it, future generations will depend on it. As leaders and actors within the global economy, we must bear the responsibility to bring this vision to life. We’re working to redefine the culture of accountability in business, for our companies, communities and future generations, by creating and cascading new norms of corporate leadership that can build a better world. As we work toward our vision of the future, a future where business is a force for good, we must face the policies, practices and mindsets that have brought us to a world of broken trust, rapidly rising temperatures and increasing inequality. We must confront the crisis of conformity in leadership. We believe a new formula for leadership is needed if we are to successfully navigate these challenges. We need bold and brave leaders, willing and able to transform their own practices by embracing purpose-driven and holistic leadership, with humanity at the heart, aligned with the principles of sustainability, equality and accountability. Bold Vision, Brave Action: Our Strategy To build this new way of leading, we need business to align around both a bold vision of it and the brave action it’ll require. Since our start, we've rallied behind a future where the purpose of business is to drive inclusive social, environmental and economic benefit. We continue to support business as a force for the well-being of people and our planet—creating new norms of corporate leadership. Looking ahead, we believe the need to build an inclusive economy is more urgent than ever before. The challenges to achieve it are formidable, but we must commit business to an economic future that serves all people.That’s why we’ve come together to craft a five-year strategy to set out our inclusive economy vision and inform the plans, actions and decisions we’ll take forward through to 2025. Learn More About Our Strategic Priorites Explore our inclusive economy vision and the priorities we're working toward to achieve it through 2025.
